headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Angela. Good morning, and welcome, everyone to O-I's second quarter 2011 earnings conference call. I'm joined today by Al Stroucken, our Chairman and CEO; Ed White, our Chief Financial Officer; and several other members of our senior management
componenttext:
Thank you, Angela. Good morning, and welcome, everyone to O-I's second quarter 2011 earnings conference call. I'm joined today by Al Stroucken, our Chairman and CEO; Ed White, our Chief Financial Officer; and several other members of our senior management team.
Today, we will discuss the key business developments, review our financial results for the second quarter and discuss future trends affecting our business in 2011. Following our prepared remarks, we'll host a question-and-answer session. Presentation materials for this earnings call are also being simulcast on the company's website at o-i.com. Please review the Safe Harbor comments and disclosure of our use of non-GAAP financial measures included in those materials.
Unless otherwise noted, the financial results we are presenting today relate to adjusted net earnings, which exclude certain items that management considers not representative of ongoing operations. A reconciliation of GAAP to non-GAAP earnings can be found in our earnings press release and in the appendix to this presentation.
I'll now turn the call over to Al, who will start on Q2.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John, and good morning. Our second quarter 2011 adjusted earnings were $0.59 per share, down considerably from $0.84 last year. Clearly, we are disappointed with these results and our performance was unacceptable. Adding into the second quarter
componenttext:
Thank you, John, and good morning. Our second quarter 2011 adjusted earnings were $0.59 per share, down considerably from $0.84 last year. Clearly, we are disappointed with these results and our performance was unacceptable. Adding into the second quarter, we expected our earnings would be in line with the prior year despite elevated cost inflation. However, we incurred significantly higher manufacturing costs, which more than offset the benefit of higher shipments on a global basis.
Market demand has started to rebound after several years of unfavorable trends in our business. Shipments from were up more than 6% in the second quarter, driven by recent acquisitions as well as organic growth. In fact, demand was up across all key and end user categories on a global basis. This should have been a very favorable environment for O-I given our work in the past to create significant operating leverage from improving demand. However, we incurred much higher manufacturing costs due to elevated cost inflation, production issues in North America and market challenges in Australia and New Zealand. Cost inflation accounted for most of the additional manufacturing costs while inflation was not a surprise, energy rises in Europe have increased faster and to a greater extent than we expected adding into the year. And we have discussed this trend in detail during previous earnings call. 
We have implemented an energy surcharge in Europe to help offset the impact of the most recent spike in energy pricing. The combination of our surcharge this year and expected higher selling prices next year should fully offset the impact of 2011 cost inflation on a global basis.
In North America, core operating performance resulted in manufacturing inefficiencies and supply chain issues. As a result, we incurred higher production and logistics costs as well as additional expenses for product loss. Challenging market conditions in Australia and New Zealand resulted in choppy, lower demand in those countries. And in response, we reduced our production to match supply with demand, which led to higher unabsorbed fixed cost in Asia-Pacific.
As we responded with urgency with these issues, my leadership team and I are focusing on our core operations to restore higher product productivity level. We also need to significantly improve our ability to you generate a more accurate business forecast. Serving our customers and maximizing our long-term earnings are our highest priorities. Despite our disappointing operating performance, we confirm a number of positive developments this quarter. Organic growth was 3%, excluding the impact of the much lower demand in Australia and New Zealand. We generated $97 million of free cash flow and we acquired the remaining interest in our 7 Brazil operations from our minority partner. O-I will fully benefit from future growth and productivity improvement in the attractive Brazilian market. And finally, we refinanced debt to extend maturities and increase financial flexibility. 
Looking to the third quarter, we expect shipments will be up in all regions and end-users in year-over-year basis. As we focus on fully resorting our operating performance, we will still incur higher manufacturing costs during this transition period. And as a result, we expect third quarter adjusted earnings will improve from our second quarter results but likely lag the prior year. Looking to the full year, we have revised our 2011 free cash flow target for a number of reasons. In Australia, we are restructuring our footprint in response to changes in demand. This will result in additional capital spending and severance costs. In North America, we will rebuild inventory levels to avoid repeating significant supply change disruptions and improve boost. And in Europe we expect some restructuring costs as part of the purchase price of our recent DDL acquisition. And finally, we will invest in capacity expansion in South America to improve margins and support growth.  As a result, our 2011 free cash flow target has been reduced from $300 million to between $200 million and $250 million. 
Now I will review each of our segments and I'll start with Europe, our largest regional chart #3.  Europe performed as expected. Operating profit was $107 million compared to $104 million in the second quarter of 2010. The benefit of favorable currency translation and higher shipments offset elevated cost inflation. Shipments were up mid-single digits in Europe as demand grew across all key end-use segments. Selling prices were flat with the prior year, reflecting the annual contracts negotiated last year when supply demand conditions and inflation levels we're much softer and those we are experiencing today. In response to the higher cost inflation, we have successfully negotiated energy surcharges of approximately $50 million to $20 million in the second half of the year. Overall, we expect to fully pass on the impact of 2011 cost inflation on Europe to our surcharge this year and higher prices next year. And in the future, we plan to include prospective inflation provisions into our annual customer agreements there. 
Several days ago, we announced the acquisition of BBL, which operate the single-glass plant in France, located near the Nestle Water facility. We have strengthened our strategic relationship with Wesley and are now the leading glass container provider for both their that Central Belgrade in France and Italy, respectively. 
Moving to Chart 4. Our South American operations also performed as expected and generated operating profit of $53 million in the second quarter, up from $49 million last year. Volumes were up more than 35% year-over-year. Our strategic acquisitions last year accounted for most of this growth. But the region also posted double-digit organic growth driven by Brazil, Argentina and Peru. But the benefit of higher shipments was mostly offset by higher costs. So segment operating -- sorry, segment profit margin was about 18%, which was lower than we typically see in this region for a few reasons. First, we incurred additional cost inflation. Our second quarter prices were flat with the prior year, we expect to recapture cost inflation through higher prices beginning in the third quarter.
Second, our Brazilian operations were sold out and we shipped glass from other countries in the region to meet growing Brazilian demand. These shipments had associated freight and infiltration penalties that to meet the growing demand before we commit more capital for expansion in the region. Throughout the glass situation, we incurred some cost to realign machinery and increased capacity Brazil. And to support continued growth, we will further bottleneck our operations there. We are also planning a Greenfield plan in South America to support our customers long-term growth needs. And finally, as I mentioned already, we bought out our minority partner in our Southern Brazil operations and we expect this transaction to be accretive in 2011. 
Moving to North America on Chart #5. Adding into the second quarter, we had expected higher earnings compared to the prior year. We anticipated stronger shipments combined with footprint initiative segments. However, North American operating profit was $56 million, down from $87 million in the prior year. Most of the decline was due to $26 million from production inefficiency, higher freight cost and product loss. Due to a number of operating issues, we were not able to meet all of our customers' needs. And as a result, shipments in North America were down slightly despite some amount of strength in all key end-use markets other than the. 
We have always prided ourselves on our operational excellence and our ability to meet or exceed our customers expectations. We failed to meet those standards in the second quarter but we expect to significantly improve our service level in the back half of the year. The graph from Chart 5 depicts the chain of events that led to our issues in the region this quarter. And keep in mind that the last resort from those represent specific data. The blue line represents our effective manufacturing capacity while the yellow line illustrates seasonal demand pattern. We permanently closed 2 plants in North America and mid-2010 to realign capacity with lower demand following the conclusions of contract negotiations with key customers. Given soft demand last year, we were focused on efficient working capital levels and we maintain tight inventories as we entered 2011. On the green line represents inventory levels to show relative trend. But again, it's illustrative. Then as 2011 progressed, several things happened. First, demand started pick up in North America but the growth was in wine, spirits and craft beer and up in. This mix created additional complexities that we underestimated. For example, more SKUs result in shorter production runs, which require greater flexibility in our platform. 
We struggled with a greater number of in several pants and did not achieve the same production efficiency that we typically see with the Mega Beer brands. Second, we add a number of production introductions that require downtime for repairs. As you can see, this downtime coincided with seasonally stronger demand. As a result, we did not achieve the productivity improvements that we expected in the second quarter.
And third, longer lead times on repair parts delayed the anticipated restart of 2 previously idle, so we did not get the much-needed additional capacity of staff as we had expected. As a result of these issues, tight inventory became short inventory at several locations. And to serve our customers, we had to reallocate production to other facilities in North America. And this in turn disrupted those plans, normal manufacturing patterns, which led to incremental costs. Since production sometimes occur at plants hundreds of miles away from the customer, we also incurred significant higher freight cost, all of which unfortunately coincided with spiking diesel costs. You can see the domino affect that started with production issues earlier in the quarter. Now to address these issues, we have initiated a plan to both restore our inventories to sustainable levels and improve production efficiency over the course of the second half of the year.
First, we're taking immediate action to rebuild inventory. We have restarted over 2 previously furnaces and they are up and running by early July. This added approximately 5% more production capacity to the region. We are also leveraging our global footprint by shifting glass from other regions to increase North American inventories by about 5%. And finally, our North American plants will of course run at high operating rates through the end of the year.
As a result of these actions, we expect to rebuild North American inventories and reduce the risk of significant future supply-chain competitions. Over that six-month, we are focusing on returning to operational excellence in North America. Most of our inefficiencies during the second quarter was tied to discrete production issues, which we do not expect to recur. Nevertheless, we are conducting thorough manufacturing audits of our 19 North American facilities to determine if there are any unidentified production risks. Of course we will take necessary actions to remove the if anything is found. Finally, we are actively collaborating with our customers to improve the SKU accuracy of their demand forecast, as well as our production forecast. This will help avoid the many unplanned changes and changeovers that compromise productivity. A more effective supply chain will benefit both O-I and our customers. And for future customer contracts, we look to include provisions and forecast accuracy to create clarity about supply commitments and ownership of cost variances.
To avoid additional disruption in those difficult period, we have delayed our SAP implementation in North America until early 2012. Let me reiterate. Our second quarter performance in North America was unacceptable and full remediation of these issues is priority number one. 
Now moving to our North America to Asia Pacific on Chart 6. Adding into the second quarter, we expected that our Asia-Pacific profits will be down from the prior year as a result of lower demand in Australia and New Zealand. We've been discussing this trend over the past 2 quarters. However, actual results were significantly lower than anticipated. Asia-Pacific earned $9 million, down $22 million from the prior year. Of the total regional shipments we're up slightly from the prior year, all growth was attributable to our 2010 acquisitions in China. Our shipments of wine and beer bottles in Australia and New Zealand were down nearly 20% from the prior year. This resulted in $7 million of lower profit contribution from sales. In macroeconomic headwinds drove the specific drop in shipments from these 2 countries. Stronger currencies negatively impacted the wine exports and lead to some fundamentally different approaches by our wine customers to their future business models. Domestically, function was down considerably as high interest and savings rate have lowered consumers' disposable income, and this has cost a severe cutback in consumer spending.
While we anticipated lower shipments, demand trends in the wine and beer markets deteriorated faster than expected in the second quarter. In particular, Australia wine producers reduced bottling given the dramatic increase in the value of Australian dollar. In response, we reduced production to balance supply with lower demand, resulting in $10 million of unabsorbed manufacturing cost on top of the contribution from lower cost. Given these developments, we are taking the following actions. First, we recently named Steve Brandich the new President of the Asia-Pacific region and replaced Brad who is leaving the company. Brad will report to me and serve the number of the global leadership team. He previously served as the Treasurer and Vice President of Finance for O-I, and more recently as the General Manager of our New Zealand operations. We believe Steve will provide a fresh perspective to address the market challenges in the region.
Second, some of the issues that we face in Australia are longer term in nature, and as a result, we will need to properly align our capacity with changing long-term demand. We will restructure our Australia operations in several days. In July, we implemented the first phase by permanently closing one machine wine in Australia and toward the immediate future, other supply and demand imbalances will be managed through continued temporary bounce off. 
The next phase of our restructuring plan will likely require additional permanent capacity adjustment in Australia. This plan must ensure that we retain the right capabilities and invest in the necessary technologies for our customers. Also, we need to maintain flexibility to meet future demand levels in the event of an upstream in the market. Australia is now answering its seasonally strongest periods so it's prudent to delay restructuring activities until later this year. And we expect that restructuring will conclude by the mid-2012. This restructuring in this region may result in up to $50 million of capital expenditures and severance costs. Up to half of this cost will be incurred in 2011 and the balance would fall into 2012. Overall, these actions should improve our cost profile in Australia and I will keep you updated on our decisions regarding this quote on implementation of restructuring activities in future earnings calls. 
Now moving to Chart 7. We remain committed to our long-term strategy, which continues to deliver value for O-I. For example, our focus on operational excellence have generated $245 million of savings between 2007 and 2010, driven by our footprint alignment initiative. As we refocus on our core operations, we have been redesigning our organizational structure in each region. We are bringing manufacturing and supply chain functions under one regionally integrated operations. This structure will remove the functions in our operations and provide a more holistic approach to optimize the entire process. And this will allow maximize operational efficiency and provide better visibility and control over production costs. 
Regarding strategic and profitable growth, in 2010, we acquired 10 plants located in fast-growing emerging markets that are generating an average operating profit margin of approximately 20% and creating significant growth momentum. Last March, our new market approach has enhanced the effectiveness of our organic marketing efforts and has boosted our growth in South America 5 to 7 percentage points above average market growth. And while we're already seeing success in our other regions as we replicate this initiative globally. New capabilities like Vortex or Lean+Green line bottles and break glass are driving additional sales in all regions. While the strategies are driving value, a number of other factors have undermined our ability to generate the improved financial performance that we expected when we set our longer-term targets back in 2010. And these factors include, first, the economic downturn impacted the markets that we serve longer than we expected at that time, especially with continued high unemployment in the developed market. And also the Vega beer brand have not recovered as we anticipated when we were exiting the recession. 
Second, the of our highly profitable Venezuelan operations and of course throughout the challenge with our operating performance that I discussed in detail with you. And finally, I believe that at present, our current earnings profile does not support acquisitions of the magnitude, speed and impact that we discussed at the last investor day. Given these developments, it is unlikely that we will achieve the longer-term targets that we discussed earlier last year, and we're currently revisiting these targets. I will now turn the call over to Ed.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Al. Let's move to Chart 8. We included much of this information in our press release and in-house comments so I will only touch on the highlights. Second quarter 2011 segment sales increased nearly 17%, the more than $1.9 billion. Recent acquis
componenttext:
Thank you, Al. Let's move to Chart 8. We included much of this information in our press release and in-house comments so I will only touch on the highlights. Second quarter 2011 segment sales increased nearly 17%, the more than $1.9 billion. Recent acquisitions and improving market conditions improved more than 6% increase in tons shipped. This boosted the top line by $97 million. You can also see that currency translation substantially increased the top line especially in Europe. Moving over to segment operating profit. The second quarter was $225 million compared to $271 million last year. Higher volumes contributed $26 million but manufacturing and delivery costs increased by $78 million. Higher costs were largely driven by $61 million of cost inflation as expected but an additional $26 million of North American production issues and another $10 million unabsorbed fixed cost in Australia and New Zealand were not foreseen. Finishing with the EPS reconciliation.
Our adjusted net income was $0.59 per share in the quarter compared $0.84 in the prior year. Lower operating profit reduced earnings $0.21 in the prior year. Earnings were impacted $0.04 from unfavorable nonoperating item, largely due to higher interest expense on incremental debt to fund 2010 acquisitions. Retain corporate costs were about flat from the prior year. Higher marketing spending and non-cash pension expenses were offset by $10 million of lower management compensation, which reflects adjustments to both the incentive plans and the impacted lower 2011 earnings. Also, the merger of businesses in Brazil resulted in a tax benefit. Finally, we had 2 note  one expenses this quarter as outlined in our earnings release. 
Let's move to Chart 9 for more detail on our balance sheet, cash flow and capital structure. On June 30, 2011, cash was $260 million in total debt was approximately $4.3 billion. The net debt was $4.1 billion, an increase of more than $1.2 billion from the prior year's second quarter, reflecting financing for acquisitions made last year and the impact of foreign currency translation on our debt. Our net debt to EBITDA ratio was at 3.2, just like at the end of the second quarter, well below the bank covenants limit of 4x. However, our ratio now exceeds our leverage target of between 2x and 3x EBITDA. So future debt reduction will be a priority. We believe this range represents an efficient capital structure for O-I and provides the financial facility needed to execute our strategy.
Free cash flow was $97 million in the second quarter compared to a $6 million use of cash last year. Lower working capital levels and capital spending more than offset a decline in earnings. Let me shift now to our capital allocation priorities and repeat what Al has said. We are clearly disappointed with our results this quarter and we impact that this has had on the O-I share price and on our shareholders. At our current stock price, we understand that the share buyback maybe viewed as a compelling use of cash. However, we need to focus on debt reduction to lower our leverage to below 3x EBITDA by year end 2011. Further, it is essential that we dedicate some of our current year cash flow to restructure our Australia, to rebuild inventories in North America and to begin to expand capacity in South America. 
Turning to capital expenditures. Our 2011 estimate has been reset. We now expect up to $375 million of CapEx given the restructuring and capacity expansion I just mentioned. Finally, we're very pleased with the successful completion of our $2 billion bank credit agreement earlier in the second quarter. We also redeemed in the second quarter higher cost senior notes using attractively priced term debt. On Chart 10, we presented business outlook for the third quarter. There are clearly many moving parts in our business especially as we are taking actions to address our operating performance. As a result, we're providing the actual outlook on operating profit on this segment for an operational cost and overall adjusted earnings.
Our European third quarter profit should be in line with the prior year. We expect earnings will benefit from higher volumes and energy surcharges. Yet cost inflation will remain elevated during the third quarter. As on the right, global cost inflation in excess of price will likely impact O-I's 2011 margins by more than $130 million, which we expect to recapture with the highest pricing mostly in 2012. In North America, we expect segment operating profit will lag the prior year. However, the manufacturing cost penalties we incurred in the second quarter should moderate as we increase capacity one full and improve operational and supply chain efficiencies over the course of the quarter. 
Our segment for Asia Pacific operating performance will remain below prior-year earnings, given continued temporary production curtailment in Australia and New Zealand. However, earnings should benefit on a sequential basis from seasonally stronger demand. In South America, segment operating profit should improve from the prior year. We anticipate shipments will remain very strong and we also expect higher selling prices as we pass through inflation incurred in the first half of 2011. Turning demand operational items. We expect higher year-over-year corporate cost with the continued sales and marketing initiatives and the higher pension expenses we've seen all year. Further details are provided on the chart. 
Overall, we expect the operating performance to improve over the close of the third quarter, but we will still incur high manufacturing costs during the transition. Before we expect the third quarter adjusted earnings to improve in the second quarter, it will likely lag the prior-year third quarter results. Now I will turn the call back to Al for closing remarks on Chart 11.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: As said, while this has been a struggling quarter for O-I, we should not lose sight that our business fundamentals remain strong, many glass markets are strengthening and we have the tools and capabilities that we need to refocus our operations. We have a
componenttext:
As said, while this has been a struggling quarter for O-I, we should not lose sight that our business fundamentals remain strong, many glass markets are strengthening and we have the tools and capabilities that we need to refocus our operations. We have a very good understanding of what went wrong over the last few months and we have taken this situation very seriously and realize that we disappointed our investors as well as some customers. We're implementing corrective action plans in North America and Asia Pacific as described and we expect to bring the operating performance of both regions up to the high standards that we have demonstrated in the past. 
We now expect free cash flow for 2011 to be in the range of $200 million to $250 million and we're focusing our capital allocation on remediation plans, expansion in South America and debt reduction. Further, we do not foresee any significant acquisitions at this time in the second half of 2011. And as you can see, our priorities are focused on operational excellence in the near term, which ultimately is the foundation of our long-term strategy. Thank you, and now I will let Angela to open up the lines for your questions.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And your first question is from Alex Ovshey with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And your first question is from Alex Ovshey with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: You mentioned that you're hoping to raise prices in Europe in 2012 to more than offset inflation you saw in 2011 but also to think about getting out of inflation 2012. Could you just talk about the level of confidence in being able to achieve that and how
componenttext: You mentioned that you're hoping to raise prices in Europe in 2012 to more than offset inflation you saw in 2011 but also to think about getting out of inflation 2012. Could you just talk about the level of confidence in being able to achieve that and how of work that you actually expect the restructure and the contracts were beyond 2012 you have that ability or is it just the fact that things have tightened up in Europe. But at least for 2012 you feel reasonably good that you could be able to get in front of the inflation in Europe.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think Europe, as you know, is a market we're about 70% or 80% of our volume is really tied to annual contracts so we have the opportunity to reset the price levels every year. However, what we have seen in the past as well, Europe is also a market where
componenttext: I think Europe, as you know, is a market we're about 70% or 80% of our volume is really tied to annual contracts so we have the opportunity to reset the price levels every year. However, what we have seen in the past as well, Europe is also a market where normal passthrough provisions have an actual or have an additional dependency and that is the supply-demand picture. So if supply is long and demand is weak, you have a very difficult to pass through inflation. One is supply and demand is balanced as we are seeing this year and in fact in the peak season, we see supply is outstripped by demand. You really then get pricing power. And one of the indications that this gives me the confidence for next year, the fact that we went into the market with a surcharge, that we were able to negotiate with our customers in quite a few countries, finished successfully and that I believe gives me the confidence that we are seeing some good opportunity for price improvement. Equally, we have been negotiating certain longer-term contracts that were reset in the course of this year because we do not what will come by the end of the year and in some of those cases, in most of those cases that I'm aware of, we have been able to raise our prices mid to high-single digits. So I think that indicates that there is some pricing power that is being regained in the marketplace.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. Can you just talk about the demand trends that you're seeing across the key markets in Europe and the way you're seeing the most competitors and perhaps you may still be seeing sluggish on the wine activity.
componenttext: That's helpful. Can you just talk about the demand trends that you're seeing across the key markets in Europe and the way you're seeing the most competitors and perhaps you may still be seeing sluggish on the wine activity.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Overall Europe has been growing and virtually all applications, even in the beer sector. A lot of the growth in the beer that we've seen in Europe has come from exports and we covered export markets for the traditional export brands. But the driver of the
componenttext: Overall Europe has been growing and virtually all applications, even in the beer sector. A lot of the growth in the beer that we've seen in Europe has come from exports and we covered export markets for the traditional export brands. But the driver of the growth has been liquor has been wine, improved as the overall underlying consumption of those products improved. And I believe it's also indicative of the longer-term trend that we are observing that those brands of those products allow customers to be more individualistic in their choice of beverage would favor the wine, the liquor as well as the micro brewer brands than the Mega brands. And I think we will continue to see that trend for quite a while.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: And your next version is from the line of Ghansham Panjabi with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: And your next version is from the line of Ghansham Panjabi with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: It looks like you guys are seeing a dislocation in Australia based at least in part due to currency. Brazil also has a very strong currency, which some of your peers and your customers are saying is affecting local demand. Why shouldn't we expect your Bra
componenttext: It looks like you guys are seeing a dislocation in Australia based at least in part due to currency. Brazil also has a very strong currency, which some of your peers and your customers are saying is affecting local demand. Why shouldn't we expect your Brazilian business to also face potential volumes? Also what kind of demands in area are you breaking in for the capacity that you're adding?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: We're seeing quite some strong growth in the high-single digits in Brazil as far as organic growth is concerned, of course some additions in the acquisitions that we made. We have been seating the markets with imported product at this point in time. So wh
componenttext: We're seeing quite some strong growth in the high-single digits in Brazil as far as organic growth is concerned, of course some additions in the acquisitions that we made. We have been seating the markets with imported product at this point in time. So whatever we're putting in place as far as additional capacity is not for future demands that has not yet materialized with items have already existing demand over serving from our higher cost bases. With regards to the currency impact, comparing it to Australia, really, the issue in Australia it is one of having such a significant export component and a units consumer of glass which the wine industry represents. When I look at our demand profit in Brazil, virtually, almost all with very few exceptions, left than 1% am I would say, is consumed domestically. There is not a lot of exports of Brazilian brands into the rest of the world. So I would say that based on the information that we have at this point in time and also the growth that we saw continue in the second quarter, Brazil still continues to be on a very positive path for us going forward and we have to be ready to serve the demand. I know you have heard and you have seen that a lot of new capacity is added the in the aluminum industry as well, looking forward to a continued growth in Brazil. And I think that there too, there is a level of confidence that certainly in the long-term, Brazil will continue to be significant contributor to the growth profile of their business.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Got it. And just one follow-up, since you pre-announced in mid-June and switching to North Napa, I think on the margin in the spending environment in North America is worse, not better, and here you are ramping up inventory, because you obviously run out
componenttext: Got it. And just one follow-up, since you pre-announced in mid-June and switching to North Napa, I think on the margin in the spending environment in North America is worse, not better, and here you are ramping up inventory, because you obviously run out of stuff in the quarter so you can produce fast enough. How do we know -- what gives you comfort that you're not going to overproduce by the back end of the year, and we're going to have the opposite part in 2012.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Because we can surely rapidly see, as we see the weakening in demand occurring in the second half of the year and our production is ramping up fast, then we will have to eventually make a judgment and say, okay, we're not going to meet that inventory, fun
componenttext: Because we can surely rapidly see, as we see the weakening in demand occurring in the second half of the year and our production is ramping up fast, then we will have to eventually make a judgment and say, okay, we're not going to meet that inventory, fundamental conditions of the market change. And of course, while all a little bit empty at this point in time with regards to what the issues related to foreign severance debt or sovereign debt have to with the overall economic impact. I mean, if we do not get to a resolution in the United States over the next week, that may have considerable repercussions on a global scale. So there is a level of uncertainty there but I think the instrument that we're using is an instrument an instrument that we can fairly quickly then adjust and correct. So it's not something that we make a decision today and then we have to live with it for the next year. This is the seasonality of our business always make the fourth quarter, especially the month of December, the natural throttle for our inventory adjustments that we deal year-over-year.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from George Staphos from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And your next question is from George Staphos from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. First on operations. Al, are there any facilities right now where you are producing from a sub-optimal level relative to the mix of products, that you're making wine bottles on their machines, you're making mayonnaise on triple pan,
componenttext: A couple of questions. First on operations. Al, are there any facilities right now where you are producing from a sub-optimal level relative to the mix of products, that you're making wine bottles on their machines, you're making mayonnaise on triple pan, is there any of that right now in your operations? And where to point, how long do you think it will take the North America to get out of this operational issue?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think a lot of that was covered with the that we did a year, 1.5 year ago. So we don't have a lot of that happening. The issue is much more -- that because of the demand of individual SKUs, we have to shift volumes for one facility to the other but stil
componenttext: I think a lot of that was covered with the that we did a year, 1.5 year ago. So we don't have a lot of that happening. The issue is much more -- that because of the demand of individual SKUs, we have to shift volumes for one facility to the other but still be a beer unit or would still be a beer facility, but it might not be in proximity. So it would be a couple of hundred miles away, which of course added significantly to the logistics cost. The other part that really contributed to the cost as well as due to the changeovers. During the changeover periods, we create quite a bit of material that we cannot really sell, that we have to reuse in our operations and then of course contribute significantly to the product loss. But fundamentally, from an infrastructure perspective, we are basically placed very well. I believe one thing that we perhaps misinterpreted and misunderstood was that facilities that typically were used to run wine, beer for a particular brand and suddenly have to have a lot more changeovers, have difficulty spiking with that additional complexity.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: So how long do you think it will take to get off from this? And then the second question I have was, as I look back to what happened in the quarter it would seem that there was not necessarily the level of communication that you would have liked within yo
componenttext: So how long do you think it will take to get off from this? And then the second question I have was, as I look back to what happened in the quarter it would seem that there was not necessarily the level of communication that you would have liked within your business groups, have you that if you agree with that climate, how do you incentivize that going forward and how do you feel about your information system? Do you get the information you need to manage this going forward?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Okay, well with regards to the information systems, that of course was the implementation of SAPs to get better structure information flow and information system. It also follows a process rather than is aligned to functions that we've been working on. Cl
componenttext: Okay, well with regards to the information systems, that of course was the implementation of SAPs to get better structure information flow and information system. It also follows a process rather than is aligned to functions that we've been working on. Clearly, we're not communicating well enough at the beginning of the quarter to understand the issues and complexities. I believe a decision was made to serve the customers at all cost, which I think is a very conclusion. And that, however, lead them to complexities we've created for ourselves rather than perhaps also working with the customers to get greater accuracy in their forecast. But it's clearly our fault. We have to fix it and we have to deal with that. And I can assure you, that the information flow and communication has increased quite a bit over the last couple of weeks to make sure that we don't have the same occurrence in the future.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2011

componenttext: And your next question is from the line of Bill Cresh with JPMorgan.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Clearly this year, we're talking about the opportunity for significant incremental margins in the developed markets. Looks like you did achieved that in Europe this quarter. Obviously there is the operational issues in North America but I guess, what I'm
componenttext: Clearly this year, we're talking about the opportunity for significant incremental margins in the developed markets. Looks like you did achieved that in Europe this quarter. Obviously there is the operational issues in North America but I guess, what I'm wondering is, specifically in North America, where you're talking about more SKUs and shorter runs in craft beers, wines, spirits, et cetera, does that kind of take off the table, that the potential for these higher incremental margins on a recovery in the future or how are you thinking about that now?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: It doesn't. It really just reinforcing the higher margins because typically, of course, we have smaller SKUs, we also tend to get higher pricing points and better margins. It's really the operational flexibility that you have to have in place. And we fort
componenttext: It doesn't. It really just reinforcing the higher margins because typically, of course, we have smaller SKUs, we also tend to get higher pricing points and better margins. It's really the operational flexibility that you have to have in place. And we fortunately have examples. In Latin America and in Europe, where we have for many years, have this flexibility because many of these plants serve quite a variety of uses and of applications. And clearly also have a great number of customers. Whereas in the United States, the entire customer environment spend more and we've been being focusing on large deals as our main focus areas in the past. And we just felt at the time when we entered into a more proactive pursuit of these smaller SKUs and higher pricing points, because we have the capability in the company that we would have the capability in North America as well. And I think that's really where we perhaps misunderstood the complexity of absolutely plan-per-floor and top floor and that's where we are taking corrective actions at this point in time. But that certainly doesn't stand in the way of higher margins.

componenttext: Okay. And then in North America, you talked about the volume. Do you have any color on that?

componenttext: Well, I think pricing in the United States was slightly down but basically, what that also cost by the fact that we have faster provisions for energy and energy in the United States have decreased from last year. So the U.S. is behaving a little bit difficult to the rest of the world with regards to energy inflation.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: No. The mix in Latin America has predominantly to do with the fact that we are importing products and supply the market and the sales -- we're talking Brazil so we're importing from Columbia, Peru and that of course has quite a bit of shipping cost, wareh
componenttext: No. The mix in Latin America has predominantly to do with the fact that we are importing products and supply the market and the sales -- we're talking Brazil so we're importing from Columbia, Peru and that of course has quite a bit of shipping cost, warehousing cost and implication cost attached to it. And that's really compressing the margin. That's also the justification, of course, to build capacity locally because then you'll automatically get margin expansion because you no longer occurring those costs and so the investment's really paying for itself.

componenttextpreview: Given the many thousand customers that we have in Europe, it's very difficult to really speak of a pattern. I mean, what we did see is of course higher demand in the marketplace. Now we have to see as we come out of the high season, how much of that was a
componenttext: Given the many thousand customers that we have in Europe, it's very difficult to really speak of a pattern. I mean, what we did see is of course higher demand in the marketplace. Now we have to see as we come out of the high season, how much of that was anticipatory orders because we knew the market was tight, so than will perhaps place 2 orders rather than one order. Because I may need that additional volume and then if I have to order in short notice I might not get it. So we have to balance a little bit as we're coming out of the high season, all of the demand we're seeing was really actual shipments on the part of the customers. But a good sign -- despite the fact that we were the first ones out with an energy surcharge in the marketplace, we were reasonably successful and where we are in the market leader in the country. And I believe that indicates that demand is still performing at a fairly decent levels even though we keep hearing from our customer base that a lot of their demand was not coming from Europe, but it's coming from increased exports.

componenttext: Well you got 2 things. One, in the first half, we reversed some accruals from incentives that I talked about in the prepared remarks of almost $10 million. So although we go down, we're still doing some of the configurations was still going on, which is also a lot of it is embedded in the corporate center.

componenttextpreview: I guess first off in the Australian markets, you mentioned beer and wine shipments being down 20%. Could you breakout how much of that might be due to currency and if it should come back, if we see currency stabilize versus how much should be permanent lo
componenttext: I guess first off in the Australian markets, you mentioned beer and wine shipments being down 20%. Could you breakout how much of that might be due to currency and if it should come back, if we see currency stabilize versus how much should be permanent long-term demand loss?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, Alton, I believe that, of course, the 64-million-dollar question for the customers as well. But I believe they were hoping throughout the entire year last year that eventually currency would weaken, and they would be able to reoccupy the shelf space
componenttext: Well, Alton, I believe that, of course, the 64-million-dollar question for the customers as well. But I believe they were hoping throughout the entire year last year that eventually currency would weaken, and they would be able to reoccupy the shelf space for their wine. And typically, you go into the stores, you find Australia and New Zealand line has a particular price range, generally at its around $10 price level. And with -- right now, the Australian dollar at $1.10 to the U.S. dollar versus $0.70 or so a year, 1.5 year ago, of course the entire margin have disappeared in that business. And to try to reprice the product would require rebranding because people are not going to buy the same brand they used to buy for $10 for $20. So that's a very long-term proposition. I believe that fundamentally, we've been come to the conclusion that long-term, given the continued demand for basic raw materials in Australia, most probably the currency will continue to be at a high-level and therefore, that situation is not likely to change. So you see why the dramatic and significant change over from packets to shipments, packets product shipments to bulk shipments. They're not giving up on the market but they're approaching the market in a different model and that of course does not affect the overall consumption of glass on a global scale because what we're losing and Australia and New Zealand, we may be picking up, and picking up in North America and that's why we're seeing in North America for instance a fairly strong trend for wine bottles at this point in time. So it's a fairly complex equation but I don't think that we can expect that the Australian dollar is going to weaken so significantly that we can we reoccupy the price.

componenttext: Well those costs are basically reflected in the second quarter. So as we go into 3Q, we're coming out of this hole so it's going to be a gradual improvement that we're going to be working on in Q3 and Q4 to improve that. I would say that most probably, most significant improvement we will see initially is in reduction of freight cost because we are moving into a position where we've added additional capacity to our operations with those 2 furnaces and that would help us, hopefully help us a little bit to avoid these shipments that had so significantly contributed to the cost overrun.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q2 2011 Earnings Call, Jul 28, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, we have to keep in mind, when we look at the numbers for this year, we are in a year that's typical for the glass industry, which is coming out of the period of low inflation, moving into a period of inflation, the glass industries, margins, always
componenttext: Well, we have to keep in mind, when we look at the numbers for this year, we are in a year that's typical for the glass industry, which is coming out of the period of low inflation, moving into a period of inflation, the glass industries, margins, always are compressed. We have tried to cover up some of that in the past by making sure that in the long-term agreements and contracts we have quarterly or monthly passer provisions for the most volatile cost component. But if you have considerable increases in raw material, if you have considerable increases in labor cost, or if you have considerable increases in energy prices in those markets where you don't have long-term contracts as the provisions, you will automatically get a contraction or compaction of your margin. What we then also typically find is that when we go down in the following year, where most of that inflation is one of stores, we typically see margin expansion. Because that's when these inflationary forces will be best in the pricing and pricing arrangements we have with our customers. So I would say what we're seeing today is not necessarily indicative of a because in our overall objective as far as margin contribution from the glass industry is concerned. It is just that because of the way contracts are set up, it really has quite a bit of variability from year-to-year depending on when inflation and what please inflation rose.

And I would expect that our margins are going to be back over the 20% level in Latin America in the second half of this year.

componenttext: What changing is that they used to basically bottle their wine the Australian region. They're trying to reduce the labor cost in the country so what they're doing is basically putting the wine into large containers and shipping these bulk of oversees than basically bottling in the market of destination. And the market of destination, lower cost labor costs are high and comparable with Australia it safe to breakeven their destination markets, labor costs are low, the added benefit of low labor cost as well as reduced rate. And that is allowing them to at least occupy the shelf space rather margin that is better than the margin they're getting at this point in time. So it's really an effort on their part to take cost out of the system and still be able to serve the market and have led to significant expansion of the wine industry in Australia and New Zealand.
