headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just drill down a little bit on the cost inflation outlook on that $150 million to $180 million. How much of that is baked in as energy, where you have maybe a little less visibility on versus, I imagine, items like soda ash and labor, where m
componenttext: I wanted to just drill down a little bit on the cost inflation outlook on that $150 million to $180 million. How much of that is baked in as energy, where you have maybe a little less visibility on versus, I imagine, items like soda ash and labor, where much of that might be locked in or a lot of visibility for, I guess, the year?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's really a high level, globally. We see three buckets, and it's almost a third for each bucket between raw material inputs, energy and labor cost. And you're going to have, obviously -- we were feeling some inflation pressure on in our repair parts ope
componenttext: It's really a high level, globally. We see three buckets, and it's almost a third for each bucket between raw material inputs, energy and labor cost. And you're going to have, obviously -- we were feeling some inflation pressure on in our repair parts operating supply. But the major buckets are those three I just outlined. And because energy is a commodity and soda ash is a commodity, they really are the ones that are kind of driving the range. The labor cost, we kind of know pretty well what our contract negotiations, when they're going to end up.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: And have you locked in most of your soda ash for the year? Or is that something that could be a variable versus your expectations as it fluctuates potentially in price throughout the year?
componenttext: And have you locked in most of your soda ash for the year? Or is that something that could be a variable versus your expectations as it fluctuates potentially in price throughout the year?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: It depends, again, regionally. I think the complexity of modeling O-I is such a global company. In China, for instance, it is the China soda ash price that's moving around, which, in some ways, has an impact, a little effect across the world. Yes, we have
componenttext: It depends, again, regionally. I think the complexity of modeling O-I is such a global company. In China, for instance, it is the China soda ash price that's moving around, which, in some ways, has an impact, a little effect across the world. Yes, we have a lot of big chunks nailed down for 2011, but they're still on the margin piece of it.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just given the visibility that you do have with labor going up and the visibility on the raw materials at current prices where they are at now, just given that visibility, I know you mentioned on the price side, it's hard to argue with customers, arguing
componenttext: Just given the visibility that you do have with labor going up and the visibility on the raw materials at current prices where they are at now, just given that visibility, I know you mentioned on the price side, it's hard to argue with customers, arguing about what items are going to be at the end of the year. But just given current inflationary run rates, it would suggest that you could have argued for higher pricing to get that cost inflation covered. Am I just missing something or can you help me with some of that?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think you're missing anything. I think, however, Al, what we got to look at, as well, we must balance many factors in setting our price. We must, of course, look at inflation and inflation expectations. We also have to look at competition. We
componenttext: No, I don't think you're missing anything. I think, however, Al, what we got to look at, as well, we must balance many factors in setting our price. We must, of course, look at inflation and inflation expectations. We also have to look at competition. We have to look at the utilization rate of a factory, especially since we have, basically, downed the major price corrections. And all factors must be considered. And we must strike the right balance between price and volumes that maximize our operating profit. And I think the plan that we have at this point in time does that. If, of course, in the course of the year we see opportunity to do better than that, we will do so.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011

componenttext: And your next question is from the line Tim Thein with Citigroup.

componenttext: Price mix relative to cost inflation, are you getting or do you envision getting at price cost -- to be in a price cost-positive situation if you look by region? Do you expect that to be positive in South America?

componenttextpreview: I think South America, typically, has a much more active and proactive scenario. And as you know, we don't have really a lot of long-term agreement and long-term contracts. And also, with the strong demand in Latin America, it's safe to assume that we'll
componenttext: I think South America, typically, has a much more active and proactive scenario. And as you know, we don't have really a lot of long-term agreement and long-term contracts. And also, with the strong demand in Latin America, it's safe to assume that we'll be able to cover our inflation there.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: So the biggest spread that I had presumed, is that coming in Asia-Pac and Europe then, where you expect to be -- where you see the biggest negative from?
componenttext: So the biggest spread that I had presumed, is that coming in Asia-Pac and Europe then, where you expect to be -- where you see the biggest negative from?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think in the United States, as well. As I said, in the areas where we tend to have longer-term contracts -- and the longer-term contracts have pass-through provisions on a quarterly basis for the more volatile cost component like energy. But they only h
componenttext: I think in the United States, as well. As I said, in the areas where we tend to have longer-term contracts -- and the longer-term contracts have pass-through provisions on a quarterly basis for the more volatile cost component like energy. But they only have annual pass-through provisions for the raw materials. You automatically can see where that difference is going to come from.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Switching gears quickly, on the volume comment, just so I'm clear on that, you mentioned the kind of 40% to 60% incremental leverage in terms of organic volumes in North America and Europe. Should we expect all the acquisition and kind of greenfield expan
componenttext: Switching gears quickly, on the volume comment, just so I'm clear on that, you mentioned the kind of 40% to 60% incremental leverage in terms of organic volumes in North America and Europe. Should we expect all the acquisition and kind of greenfield expansion is coming in, or most of it, in South America and Asia-Pac, we should anticipate an incremental margin in line with segment operating margins in those two regions? Is that what you're saying, closer to high teens or 20%, is that a right assessment?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: That's right, Tim.
componenttext: That's right, Tim.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: So that would put you at a blended rate closer to the, call it, low 40s, if you look at what's been announced and what will flow in 2011, in terms of the incremental capacity. Is that a good blended average to use across the company?
componenttext: So that would put you at a blended rate closer to the, call it, low 40s, if you look at what's been announced and what will flow in 2011, in terms of the incremental capacity. Is that a good blended average to use across the company?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I'd say 30% to 40%. Why I feel that 30% out there, obviously, the growth in China, we've always been very public that our China margins are at the low end of the range. So that's why I'd be a little bit more conservative there.
componenttext: I'd say 30% to 40%. Why I feel that 30% out there, obviously, the growth in China, we've always been very public that our China margins are at the low end of the range. So that's why I'd be a little bit more conservative there.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Mark Wilde with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question is from Mark Wilde with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just a big picture, Al. When you were out here, I think, in the second quarter to present to us, you talked a lot about wanting to play more offense in the glass market, to be a little more proactive against other types of packaging. Are there any things
componenttext: Just a big picture, Al. When you were out here, I think, in the second quarter to present to us, you talked a lot about wanting to play more offense in the glass market, to be a little more proactive against other types of packaging. Are there any things that you can point to in terms of kind of tangible success so far?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the activities that we were talking about that we're going to roll out in the rest of the world for Latin America with regards to the marketing activity are really moving in that direction. For instance, look at our evolution in Latin America
componenttext: Yes, I think the activities that we were talking about that we're going to roll out in the rest of the world for Latin America with regards to the marketing activity are really moving in that direction. For instance, look at our evolution in Latin America. And even if you consider that Latin America's coming out of a recession, so some of the growth is also a recovery from a recession, it would still give us a double-digit growth in overall consumption and new businesses that we've picked up with these processes. In North America, of course, we have had some publicity with our Vortex innovation, and that also, of course, is giving some pretty good results and is going against, of course, alternative packaging, whether it's glass or whether it's other materials. I believe the real effort that we're going to engage in with these additional activities that we're pursuing is to really go after business that, in the past, already has been packaged in cans or has been packaged in plastic. And clearly, areas that are -- the greatest area for opportunity are food, as well as beverages, to really regain some of the positions that we may have lost in the past. But to do that effectively, of course, we have to have convincing projects and convincing models that we can work with, with our customers and jointly introduce this products into the marketplace.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Just as a follow-on, are there any lessons we should take from Venezuela?
componenttext: Just as a follow-on, are there any lessons we should take from Venezuela?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, of course, you can very well imagine that we've looked at this in fairly great detail. And you all know from the past that Venezuela has been a very attractive business and has really generated quite a high profit contribution to the company. And I
componenttext: Well, of course, you can very well imagine that we've looked at this in fairly great detail. And you all know from the past that Venezuela has been a very attractive business and has really generated quite a high profit contribution to the company. And I would say, looking at all factors and clearly analyzing what was going on there, even in the hindsight, I think the risk-reward ratio was right for that region. Now unfortunately, of course, what happened is not very much to our liking. But I think that, still, we have to consider that basically every country in the world has the right to nationalize industries. The question really is can we really actively still be a global company and elect to not be present in certain markets. And I think having had a presence in Venezuela for more than 40 years, or 50 years, clearly, I think it has been a good decision. It has been a good investment. And I think that the only lesson that we learned from it is to make sure that in, perhaps, some of the other countries where there is some greater volatility, we at least have actions in place and plans in place to make sure that we can deal with a situation in a proactive fashion.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011

componenttext: In the fourth quarter, you mentioned your shipments were flat year-to-year. And I was wondering what they would have been if you didn't include divestitures and acquisitions?

componenttext: I think we said that the underlying growth would have been 2%.

componenttext: It was 2%.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then second thing, you mentioned that the only sort of -- well, not the only, but one of the biggest challenges is the beer market in the mature markets, namely North America and Europe. And Al, if we saw a big comeback, let's just say it was 4%, just
componenttext: And then second thing, you mentioned that the only sort of -- well, not the only, but one of the biggest challenges is the beer market in the mature markets, namely North America and Europe. And Al, if we saw a big comeback, let's just say it was 4%, just to pick a number. In 2011, in those two markets, how much would that, do you think, impact the overall volumes? Could it be as much as 2%? Is it that big? Or maybe 1% to 2%?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say the entire market would become very tight very quickly. Not just our business, but I think the entire market would become very tight very quickly.
componenttext: Well, I would say the entire market would become very tight very quickly. Not just our business, but I think the entire market would become very tight very quickly.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: So you mean not only would there be volume business, but it might actually impact pricing as well?
componenttext: So you mean not only would there be volume business, but it might actually impact pricing as well?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, certainly, the supply-demand ratio might change, and that, of course, would have other factors well.
componenttext: Well, I think, certainly, the supply-demand ratio might change, and that, of course, would have other factors well.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: But again, on the sensitivity of it, if the beer market in those two regions did go up, again, to pick a number, I just want to know how much they are as a proportion of the overall company?
componenttext: But again, on the sensitivity of it, if the beer market in those two regions did go up, again, to pick a number, I just want to know how much they are as a proportion of the overall company?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think in our case, beer on a global basis is about half of our business. So if you have a 4% pickup in beer, that's about a considerable impact, of course, on our business. It's 2% on the overall sales.
componenttext: Well, I think in our case, beer on a global basis is about half of our business. So if you have a 4% pickup in beer, that's about a considerable impact, of course, on our business. It's 2% on the overall sales.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Chip, I would add Australia to that because if you'd looked at some of the big brewers down in Australia, their earnings calls, their consumption and consumer demands are down.
componenttext: Chip, I would add Australia to that because if you'd looked at some of the big brewers down in Australia, their earnings calls, their consumption and consumer demands are down.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: And our final question is from Peter Ruschmeier with Barclays.
componenttext: And our final question is from Peter Ruschmeier with Barclays.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I was curious if you could share your preliminary observations about the opportunities you're finding in some of the acquired businesses, whether it be China, Brazil or Argentina. Has it been meeting your expectations, and what's your experience?
componenttext: I was curious if you could share your preliminary observations about the opportunities you're finding in some of the acquired businesses, whether it be China, Brazil or Argentina. Has it been meeting your expectations, and what's your experience?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think we're very happy with the acquisitions and the improvements that we were able to make. In fact, in some of these, we have seen 10% to 15% productivity improvements in a very short period of time, which, of course, are very beneficial to the overal
componenttext: I think we're very happy with the acquisitions and the improvements that we were able to make. In fact, in some of these, we have seen 10% to 15% productivity improvements in a very short period of time, which, of course, are very beneficial to the overall return that we're projecting for these businesses. But I think what is also happening, of course, is that it is giving us access to new geographies, like for instance, in Brazil, the northern part of Brazil, we were not really very active. And that really is a fairly strongly expanding market. The other part was in Argentina. We really never had a position in Argentina, and beer demand, as well as wine, in Argentina, are evolving very nicely. Similarly, Malaysia, Vietnam, I recently was there, and it's just amazing to see the vibrancy of the economy. So I think the strategy so far is working out very well. And, certainly, in the first six to three months, depending on when we did the acquisition of the transactions that we've done, we're very satisfied and very happy with the progress that we're making.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: Within emerging markets, largely a two-way market, however, there is an emerging one-way market. I'm curious, can you comment on what you're seeing in terms of the relative growth rates of the one-way market versus the two-way market? And how has your suc
componenttext: Within emerging markets, largely a two-way market, however, there is an emerging one-way market. I'm curious, can you comment on what you're seeing in terms of the relative growth rates of the one-way market versus the two-way market? And how has your success been so far in China in terms of moving into more of the middle market?

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011
componenttextpreview: The strategy in China, clearly, was to make the acquisitions with those companies that had presence in the middle market because with what we had in place and where were located, it was very difficult to enter into that market. And so that strategy is wor
componenttext: The strategy in China, clearly, was to make the acquisitions with those companies that had presence in the middle market because with what we had in place and where were located, it was very difficult to enter into that market. And so that strategy is working out very well. With regard to the mix between one-way and refillable, I think that's really an issue that's driven by the overall income levels in those countries. And even though we have strongly emerging middle-class sections in Latin America, as well as in Asia Pacific, the overall income level relative to, let's say, Europe or North America is, of course, still very low. So what we're seeing is continued use of refillable containers as the preferable packaging modality, because it does really allow our customers to hit that emerging middle class sooner in the curve because the packaging cost is so low on a per transaction cost that it really allows them to access a broader base of the market, but sooner. And that makes it a very attractive package in their marketing strategy there as well.

headline: Owens-Illinois, Inc., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2011

componenttext: Thank you, everyone. That concludes our full year and fourth quarter earnings conference call. Please note that our first quarter 2011 conference call is currently scheduled for Thursday, April 28 at 8:30 a.m. Eastern Time. We appreciate your interest in O-I. Again, thank you, and have a good day.
